title: Target Wants to Make You a Cocktail While You Shop

components.text: Target Wants to Make You a Cocktail While You Shop

[Target](http://www.delish.com/food-news/a43508/target-grocery-delivery/), the superstore that somehow makes _everyone_ prone to impulse buys, just found a new way to get us to fork over more cash: serving cocktails and selling bottles of booze. So said Target, the superstore that somehow makes everyone prone to impulse buys, the superstore that somehow makes everyone prone to impulse buys.

At one store in Chicago, which is slated to open in October, customers could take a break from their shopping sprees and indulge in a drink (or three). According to [Crain's Chicago](http://www.chicagobusiness.com/article/20150825/BLOGS09/150829901/will-the-new-streeterville-target-have-a-bar), the new Windy City location applied for not one but two liquor licensesÑone to sell packaged booze on its shelves and the other to serve beer, wine, and spirits from a bar inside the 24,000-square-foot space.

If given approval, it will be the only Target store to serve alcohol on-site. We're crossing our fingers that there will be a few bright red signature cocktails (think [cosmopolitans](http://www.delish.com/entertaining/g2173/vodka-mixed-drinks-recipes/?slide=6), [spiked strawberry lemonade](http://www.delish.com/entertaining/a42848/thirsty-thursday-spiked-strawberry-lemonade/)) on the menu and, of course, a nationwide roll-out of this boozy concept. Because nothing else can improve a trip to the grocery store quite like a glass of rose, am I right?

While this is absolutely amazing, it will also probably definitely lead to more bad decisions when it comes to spending more cash. You know, like picking up yet another adorable set of salt-and-pepper shakers just because you have zero willpower once you step inside. I mean, who could say no to [this cute little ceramic hedgehog](http://www.target.com/p/threshold-hedgehog-pepper-shaker/-/A-15363480#prodSlot=medium_1_20&term=salt+and+pepper+shakers)? Especially while tipsy...
But I guess that's all part of the company's insanely genius (albeit evil) plan. Touche, Target.
“I started to reach in the safe and Eddie yelled, 'Wait it might be booby trapped!' I'm still laughing at that one...”

Besides the cash and the hooch, the safe also contained—and this is where it gets interesting—a book called _A Guide for the Perplexed_, published in 1977, that appears to contain clues. Inside, there was a black and white photo of a mystery (and, might we add, dapper) man. On the back of Mr. Handsome's pic, there was a note that reads:
>Alan, I have a book you must read. I've underlined a few key passages. Your friend, Vincent

There was one more poignant passage Vincent thoughtfully pointed out to Alan: "Most Modern Readers will be reluctant to believe that perfect happiness is attainable by methods of which their modern world knows nothing." Was this, perhaps the 1977 equivalent of saying, 'stop coveting that iWatch and find joy in simple walks and stuff? Unclear, but it certainly gives you pause.

_**UPDATE, 8/29:** Well, we thought it sounded too good to be true, and in fact, it was. The couple whose treasure hunt story took the Internet by storm this week have fessed up: They fabricated the whole thing. The Chive has more details on how they pulled off to the ruse. And while we feel chagrined, we're happy to see the money they "discovered" has found a good home: They donated it to a local no-kill animal shelter._
